course.name: Civil Engineering and Modern Society
course.description: An introduction to civil engineering practice and infrastructure development, with an emphasis on Hong Kong projects. The basic principles, materials and technology used in typical civil engineering works such as foundations, buildings, bridges, slopes and water supply systems, etc. Infrastructure management and maintenance issues; social-economic aspects of large-scale civil engineering projects such as environmental protection, urban planning and development, etc.

reviews.comment_teaching: Despite all those gradings stuff, teaching is quite good (at least he can deliver what we have to know and general knowledge about civil engineering). PPT is easy to follow, and he sometimes made jokes during classes, so the learning atmosphere was indeed good and relaxing. And you can obtain some extra knowledge from what he said in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% group project
30% 2 highest quizzes
50% final exam

The highest two quizzes will be counted (we have a total of 3 quizzes) and I'm around first 10% of class. I got about above 1.4 sd in final exam (90 something) and eventually got an A.

But I would give grading a D because the exam and quizzes are actually testing students' ability to memorize things instead of understanding. E.g. a question appear in past paper asking if Confederation bridge in Canada is over 1 km, true or false? One question in quizzes asking whether the Takoma bridge collasped after how long it was built (wow for god's sake am I supposed to memorize the date??). Such unnecessary questions take around 20% of your quizzes and exam. If this is why it makes people think it is a GOOD GRADE course, I really have nothing to say. But if you are not good at memorizing, please take other courses for ssc s&t.

In fact, the grading is just by a normal UST curve, nothing more than that.I was once fooled by that review, believing that it would be easy to get a decent grade, which is totally a lie. I have known a few friends from this class, getting slightly above mean wont get u an a range in SPRING. And it is rather competitive, many people got above 90. If you want a good grade, this is not for you unless you are super in memorization. Think twice before you enrol.
reviews.comment_workload:
People said the workload is low. NO FXXKING WAY. I admit that you experience light workload because you only have to attend lectures and no tutorials are needed throughout the semester. But I would say workload before quizzes and exam are UNBELIEVABLY high, if you want to score above mean and get a good grade. You have to memorize even stuff written at a small corner or something appear in a stupid picture or the height of a specific building (something like the ICC is 484m high) or where is the second tallest building in the world located, which makes people feel extremely exhausted during preparation and speechless during quizzes or exam. Especially due to the fact that final is cumulative, you have to memorize a total of 12 times 30+ pages of slides. Well, don't forget you still have other courses to study.

Alert: THIS IS FAR FROM WHAT OTHERS STATED: A LIGHT WORKLOAD AND GOOD GRADING COURSE. I definitely won't recommend this to others.

Important!! jot down notes during class

reviews.comment_workload:
It's quite heavy for a level-1000 CC, especially in Summer Semester.

First you have a group project with around 5-6 group mates. The only project guideline is given on the course outline. The topic is quite flexible, as long as it related to civil engineering like Land supply, property price in Hong Kong .etc. You have to submit both written report (within 800 words) and video presentation (2 mins per person). To be honest, the most challenging part is the written report as the content of the report is restricted by the word limits.   

Secondly, you have 3 quizzes in total, once every two weeks. It is expected to have a tight schedule as it is a summer course.

reviews.author: Grade God
reviews.comment_content: Most topics are easy. Do not require complicated concepts. Professor Hu explained clearly in class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Amazing professor.
Attending class is important because he told some midterm and final exam tips in class regularly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade.
Group project    20%
3 Quizzes each 10%
Final exam         50%

2 of the quizzes below mean, another one above mean 0.7 sd.
Final exam above mean 0.3 sd.
Professor did not told the score of projects.
Finally, I got a A-.
reviews.comment_workload:
Moderate.
Quizzes are mainly tested from the power point even some information you think it's marginal.
Group project requires a video clips introducing any one topic related to civil engineering, such as building structure.
Final exam is comprehensive but not that difficult. Revise the teaching material once or twice before exam is enough.

reviews.author: animej
reviews.title: Great course if you're good at memorisation
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction to main areas of civil engineering
2. Forces and structural principles
3. Construction materials and technology
4. Foundation systems, slopes and retaining walls
5. Buildings and basic structural forms
6. Bridges and simple analysis methods
7. Water supply systems and waste treatment
8. Deterioration and maintenance of concrete structures
9. Statistical tools and innovations in civil engineering education
10. Urban planning and land use, development and redevelopment
11. Housing in Hong Kong: social-economic impact and possible solutions
12. Transportation and society; environmental protection issues

Need to learn how to use a graphic CAS calculator (which will be loaned to you). Calculator skills take up a small portion of Quiz 2 & 3.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Quite humourous and a laid-back professor. He shows many videos to make the lectures less boring. Just remember to make notes during lectures as small details that he mentions can be covered in the quiz. Sometimes he gives hints about what might be on the quiz.

In general, he is quite responsive to emails. Sometimes, he can answer you within minutes. But since he gets a lot of emails, he can miss them sometimes.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 Quizzes: (25 + 25 + 30) = 80%
Group Project: 20%

My results:
Quiz 1: 1.3 sd above mean
Quiz 2: 0.5 sd above mean
Quiz 3: 0.9 sd above mean
Project: near full marks
Score: A-

According to the prof, the cut-off score for each grade this term is:
95.8 A+
93.2 A
89.3 A-
85.1 B+
80.5 B
73.3 B-
69.5 C+
62.0 C
48.4 C-
18.8 D

According to my calculations, only about 5 students out of 157 get A+ or A, which I think is quite harsh.
reviews.comment_workload:
There's a lot of memorisation, but since the quizzes are non-cumulative, it's not too bad.

The project is also quite easy. There were 3 choices:
(1) measurement of possible settlement in Tokwawan
(2) use of CAS technology learned from CIVL1160 to ease academic work from previous coursework (each student must do his/her own problem, to be submitted together as a group video);
(3) digitization and website preparation of “old Hong Kong database”+commentary on articles found relevant to housing/transportation/etc. (mainly for GCS majors (with some CSE majors))

Project type 1 is the most popular, and probably the easiest. All you need to do is do some measurments in To Kwa Wan and write a report/PPT (very short). We were originally meant to make a video as well, but the professor removed that requirement. Honestly, this project could easily completed even if a few group members free-ride, but don't free-ride or the prof will lower your project score.
